title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" is aimed at enhancing the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces an age limitation for claiming the tax credit on the purchase of a residence, requiring taxpayers to be at least 18 years old. Married taxpayers can meet this requirement if either spouse is of the required age. Additionally, documentation requirements are specified in the Act. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" introduces amendments to section 36 of the tax code, including changes to documentation requirements and restrictions on married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends section 36 of the tax code, including restrictions on married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse and treating certain errors related to the first-time homebuyer tax credit as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends section 36 of the tax code to include conditions for eligibility, such as age requirements, consistent income tax return information, and attaching necessary forms to the return. The amendments made by the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" to section 36 of the tax code apply to purchases, documentation requirements, and treatment of errors for taxable years after the enactment date of the Act. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Subsection (e) of section 6011 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to mandate that individual income tax returns prepared by tax return preparers be filed on magnetic media if certain conditions are met. The amendment mandates that tax return preparers file individual income tax returns electronically if they expect to file more than 100 returns in a calendar year. Additionally, a conforming amendment restricts the Secretary's ability to require electronic filing. The amendment requires tax return preparers to electronically file individual income tax returns if they anticipate filing over 100 returns in a year. It also limits the Secretary's authority to mandate electronic filing. Effective December 31, 2010.
